messages.message:
recently, when i try to rebuild a go/python docker container locally, a `kernel_task` pops up that uses >1000% CPU - based on some googling, it seems that macos is trying to prevent me from using too much CPU and overheating my computer? has anyone encountered this?

i basically need to restart my computer every time i try to test out a backend change :(
i was able to unblock myself by running `core-platform-service` locally, but i can’t do this with any python services bc i don’t have the right python dependencies locally :lolcry:

Looks like it is thermal throttling, this used to happen with me a lot with a monitor. It has been a lot better for me after updating my Mac OS version - you can try that if you’re on an older version.

Also, for backend changes would be good to run the services locally (for python services, running this script in a virtual environment should do `tools/devtools/code-dependencies/python/python37-install-dev.sh`).

exactly, i was using a monitor! and i haven’t updated my macos version ever…. :see_no_evil:

have you noticed specific benefits for running services locally vs in docker?

Oh then definitely will recommend updating, it fixed it to a large extent for me! (unplugging the monitor also works many times for a quick cooldown).
I don’t think I have ran the services with docker while making the changes - someone who has would have better idea, I was guessing running locally would eliminate the overhead and have a comparatively better resource usage.
Local is so so so much faster. For go services, you don't need to have dependencies installed
